title: American Pie
md:
# American Pie - Don Mc Lean
1. A {G}long, {D}long {e}time ago {a}I can still re{C}member how that {e}music used to make me {D}smile  
And {G}I knew {D}if I {e}had my chance that {a}I could make those {C}people dance

{e}But February {a}made me shiver {e}with every paper {a}I'd deliver  
{C}Bad news {C/B}on the {a}doorstep I {C}couldn't take one more {D}step  
I {G}can't re{D}member {e}if I cried when I {a7}read about his {D}widowed bride

~Chorus So {G}bye {C}bye Miss A{G}merican {D}Pie  
Drove my {G}Chevy to the {C}levee but the {G}levee was {D}dry  
And them {G}good old {C}boys were drinking {G}whiskey and {D}rye  
Singin' {e}this'll be the day that I {A7}die  
{e}this'll be the day that I {D7}die
2. Did you write the book of love and do you have faith in God above  
If the Bible tells you so?  
Do you believe in rock and roll? Can music save your mortal soul?  
And can you teach me how to dance real slow?  
Well, I know that you're in love with him 'cause I saw you dancin' in the gym  
You both kicked off your shoes - man, I dig those rhythm and blues  
I was a lonely teenage broncin' buck with a pink carnation and a pickup truck

4. Helter Skelter in a summer swelter, the birds flew off with a fallout shelter

With the jester on the sidelines in a cast

6. I met a girl who sang the blues and I asked her for some happy news  
But she just smiled and turned away  
I went down to the sacred store where I'd heard the music years before  
But the man there said the music wouldn't play  
And in the streets the children screamed, the lovers cried, and the poets dreamed  
But not a word was spoken - the church bells all were broken  
And the three men I admire most, the Father, Son, and the Holy Ghost  
They caught the last train for the coast the day the music died - and they were singin'

title: Black Flag Flying
md:
# Black Flag Flying - David Rovics (+2, original key: a)
1. Come {e}all you sailors near and far - you honest men know who you are

To{C}gether we will drink a toast, {G}ride the wind on down the coast

2. The war with Spain is over now - no more Jack over the bow

3. No more whips and no more chains - to live free or die is what remains

5. If I could predict the future then I would - but all I know is this is good

We may live or we may die, perhaps our destiny is nigh  
I don't know what the future may hold but I know these ships are filled with gold

title: The Foggy Dew
md:
# The Foggy Dew - Traditional (+2)
1. As {a}down the glen one {G}Easter morn to a {a}city {G}fair rode {a}I  
There {a}armed lines of {G}marching men in {a}squadrons {G}passed me {a}by  
No {C}fife did hum, nor {G}battle drum did {a}sound its {G}dread tat{a}too  
But the {a}Angelus bell o'er the {G}Liffey swell, rang {a}out through the fog{G}gy {a}dew  
2. Right proudly high over Dublin Town they hung out the flag of war  
'Twas better to die 'neath an Irish sky than at Sulva or Sud El Bar  
And from the plains of Royal Meath strong men came hurrying through  
While Britannia's Huns, with their long range guns sailed in through the foggy dew  
3. Oh the night fell black, and the rifles' crack made perfidious Albion reel  
In the leaden rain, seven tongues of flame did shine o'er the lines of steel  
By each shining blade a prayer was said, that to Ireland her sons be true  
But when morning broke, still the war flag shook out its folds in the foggy dew  
4. 'Twas England bade our Wild Geese go that small nations might be free  
But their lonely graves are by Sulva's waves or the shore of the Great North Sea  
Oh, had they died by Pearse's side or fought with Cathal Brugha  
Their names we will keep where the fenians sleep 'neath the shroud of the foggy dew  
5. But the bravest fell, and the requiem bell rang mournfully and clear  
For those who died that Easter tide in the springing of the year  
And the world did gaze, in deep amaze at those fearless men, but few  
Who bore the fight that freedom's light might shine through the foggy dew  
6. Oh, back through the glen I rode again and my heart with grief was sore  
For I parted with those valiant men whom I never shall see more  
But to and fro in my dreams I go and I'd kneel and I pray for you  
For slavery fled, O glorious dead when you fell in the foggy dew
